title: 110_hr3648
content: The "Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007" excludes discharges of indebtedness on a principal residence from gross income. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness discharged before January 1, 2010 from gross income. Special rules apply, including reducing the basis of the taxpayer's principal residence by the excluded amount. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness from gross income if discharged before January 1, 2010. This excludes acquisition indebtedness with respect to the taxpayer's principal residence. Exceptions apply for certain discharges not related to the taxpayer's financial condition. If a loan is discharged, only the portion exceeding the non-qualified amount is subject to the exclusion. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness from gross income if discharged before January 1, 2010. Exceptions apply for certain discharges not related to the taxpayer's financial condition. If a loan is discharged, only the portion exceeding the non-qualified amount is subject to the exclusion. Coordination rules prioritize the principal residence exclusion over the insolvency exclusion unless the taxpayer elects otherwise. The amendments made by this section apply to discharges of indebtedness on or after January 1, 2007, with a new subparagraph stating that the principal residence exclusion takes precedence over the insolvency exclusion unless the taxpayer elects otherwise. SEC. 3 extends the treatment of mortgage insurance premiums as interest until December 31, 2010. SEC. 4 provides alternative tests for qualifying as a cooperative housing corporation. SEC. 4 amends the definition of a cooperative housing corporation by setting requirements related to income, property usage, and expenditures for the taxable year. The amendment to the definition of a cooperative housing corporation sets requirements for income, property usage, and expenditures for the taxable year, with an effective date for taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. EXCLUSION FROM INCOME FOR BENEFITS PROVIDED TO VOLUNTEER FIREFIGHTERS AND EMERGENCY MEDICAL RESPONDERS. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new section, SEC. 139B, which excludes benefits provided to volunteer firefighters and emergency medical responders from gross income. In the case of qualified volunteer emergency response organization members, gross income excludes qualified State and local tax benefits and qualified payments. Deductions and expenses are adjusted to prevent double benefits. Qualified state and local tax benefits refer to tax reductions provided for services as a volunteer. The term 'qualified state and local tax benefit' refers to tax reductions provided by a State or political division for services as a member of a qualified volunteer emergency response organization. A 'qualified payment' is any payment provided for such services, with a limit of $30 per month. A 'qualified volunteer emergency response organization' is a volunteer organization organized to provide emergency response services. The term 'qualified state and local tax benefit' refers to tax reductions provided for services as a member of a qualified volunteer emergency response organization. The limit for a 'qualified payment' is $30 per month multiplied by the number of months the taxpayer performs services. A 'qualified volunteer emergency response organization' is organized to provide firefighting or emergency medical services and is required by a written agreement to furnish such services. This section does not apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. Subclause (I) of section 42(i)(3)(D)(ii) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to clarify student housing eligible for low-income housing credit. The amendment in section 7 applies to housing credit amounts allocated before or after the enactment date and buildings placed in service before or after that date, subject to certain conditions. SEC. 7 amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow surviving spouses to exclude up to $500,000 from capital gains tax on the sale of their principal residence within 2 years of their spouse's death. This change applies to sales after December 31, 2007. SEC. 8 modifies the penalty for failure to file partnership returns and limits disclosure. SEC. 8 amends the Internal Revenue Code by extending the time limitation for filing partnership returns to 12 months and increasing the penalty amount to $85. It also limits the disclosure of taxpayer returns to partners, S corporation shareholders, trust beneficiaries, and estate beneficiaries. The amendment restricts the disclosure of taxpayer information in partnership, S corporation, trust, or estate returns to only include information related to the entity or the person conducting the inspection. The effective date of the amendment is the date of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 9. PENALTY FOR FAILURE TO FILE S CORPORATION RETURNS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a penalty for failure to file S corporation returns. Penalty for failure to file S corporation returns under section 6037 includes a penalty for late filing or incomplete information. The penalty is $85 per month per shareholder, not exceeding 12 months, unless reasonable cause is shown. The penalty is assessed against the S corporation and deficiency procedures do not apply. The penalty for failure to file S corporation returns under section 6037 is $85 per month per shareholder, not exceeding 12 months, unless reasonable cause is shown. The penalty is assessed against the S corporation, and deficiency procedures do not apply. The amendments made by this section apply to S corporation returns required to be filed after the enactment of this Act. The percentage for corporate estimated taxes is increased by 1.50 percentage points.
